title: I have medical debt older than 4 years, how do I get collections off my credit report?
question: I had a long hospital stay over 4 years ago and disputed all charges through writing letters. I am now past the SOL on this debt and the credit reports still have left these debts on my report after disputing.
answers: Unfortunately, just because they can't sue you for it doesn't mean you don't owe it. For credit reporting purposes, we are talking 7 years here.

The SOL does not control the amount of time that a derogatory can legally stay on your credit report. Federal law governs, and says that they may report this for 7 years.

You can try to dispute the item, and if you get lucky maybe the creditor won't respond and then the item actually will drop off. You have been very lucky so far because they didn't sue you, so maybe your good luck will continue. And there is no penalty for trying unsuccessfully to dispute the item if you feel you don't owe it, so you have nothing to lose.

However something troubles me on a moral level concerning your question You seem very indignant over this bill, like how dare they try to charge you after you had a "long" stay in their hospital?

Instead of remaining for a long stay, why didn't you discharge yourself and walk out of there?

Don't you think it is likely that there would be a rather large bill after someone has a long hospital stay?

In the meantime having this as a ding on your credit may be a trivial burden on you compared to the burden that was placed on them to care for you.
